awd_titl_txt: REU Site:  Solid-State Devices for Electronics, Photonics, and Magnetics Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site program, Summer Undergraduate Research Experience in Solid-State Devices for Electronics, Photonics, and Magnetics Technology (SURE), at Clemson University, offers state-of-the-art, multi-disciplinary research experiences in the areas of electronic, photonic, and magnetic devices, including material and device design, processing, characterization and modeling, to diverse and talented cohorts of undergraduates from institutions with limited or no research opportunities. The program is intended for students who are rising juniors and seniors, majoring in electrical engineering, computer engineering, materials engineering, or related areas of mathematics, physics, and bioengineering. Micro and nanofabrication of solid-state devices are critical components of modern economic development, and diverse leadership in research on devices for electronics, photonics, and magnetics is a key to sustained US economic competitiveness.  Yet many undergraduate students have limited exposure to advanced topics in solid-state device and materials processing technology resulting in a lack of awareness and understanding of the types of research problems that arise in the field. The SURE program will be centered on the philosophy of developing tomorrow's leaders in academic and industrial research on solid-state device technology.    

The primary goal of the SURE program is to provide each undergraduate participant with a ten-week scientifically rigorous, intellectually demanding, research experience within a highly collegial environment of collaboration with faculty and other students. The program focuses on the development of the technical skills and critical-thinking abilities of the participants and on their exposure to substantive, representative research problems in device-related technology.  It will also emphasize development of the participants' technical communication abilities through several professional-development seminars and workshops and enhance their understanding of the ethical and societal context within which engineering research is performed. The discoveries made during these collaborations will be communicated to the broader scientific community via publications and presentations. 

This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

REU Site:  Solid State Devices for Electronics, Photonics, and Magnetics Technology

OUTCOMES REPORT          2022  REU Program

            Micro and nanofabrication of solid-state devices are critical components of modern economic development, and diverse leadership in research on devices for electronics, photonics, and magnetics applications is a key to sustained US economic competitiveness. Yet many undergraduate students have limited exposure to advanced topics in this field which are needed to drive the semiconductor and photonics industries. The Summer Undergraduate Research Experience in Solid-State Devices for Electronics, Photonics, and Magnetics Technology (the "SURE" program) provided undergraduate students with an in-depth ten-week directed research experience focused on this critical area of engineering and science.  It also provided professional development seminars and workshops that helped to prepare students for careers as professional engineers and scientists.

 

            The SURE program was operated as a ten-week summer research internship from summer 2017 through summer 2021 (Pandemic canceled summer 2020 + no cost extension in 2021 + no cost extension in 2022 to complete work on a supplement with local high school science teachers).  A total of 36 students from around the country participated in this summer research program during its four +-year duration.  Each student was assigned to a faculty member at Clemson University who guided them through various projects related to solid-state devices.  Graduate students working under the faculty also mentored the students and helped them with their projects in the laboratory.  Each participant explored an important open problem of current research interest using advanced methods of experimentation, analysis, and modeling.  Formal lectures, directed reading, discussion, and demonstration formed the basis for independent study and research by each student.  The program's rigorous scientific emphasis developed analytical and experimental skills based on a solid grounding in topic-specific concepts.  Our materials-to-devices paradigm for research provided a broad perspective to the participating students both theoretically and experimentally.  The faculty mentors involved in the REU have been highly successful in conducting independent, collaborative interdisciplinary research in diverse but interrelated areas ranging from fundamental materials and physics to functional devices, circuits, and systems.  The program utilized the superb laboratory facilities developed by the faculty cohort as well as those administered by Clemson University. 

 

            The SURE program was centered on the philosophy of developing tomorrow's leaders in academic and industrial research on solid-state device technology.  We focused on the selection of highly talented participants, and worked hard to instill in them a strong interest in pursuing a Ph.D. and a research-oriented career.  In preparation for this role, the program was structured to strengthen the participants' professional written and oral communication skills and enhance their understanding of the ethical and societal context within which engineering research is performed.  Thus we held multiple writing workshops and oral communications workshops to foster these skills.  Each student prepared a written technical paper, gave an oral presentation, and presented a poster describing their research project and the results.  The impact of this experience contributed significantly to their skill set in preparation for future studies and careers.

 

            To foster a diversified workforce of the future, we coordinated our recruitment efforts with Clemson’s PEER (Programs for Education Enrichment and Retention) and WISE (Women In Science and Engineering) programs to ensure a diverse group of students, in particular minority and female, were afforded access and attraction to our REU program.  Currently established relationships between our faculty and minority-serving institutions further enhanced diversity in the program.  These collaborations and agreements provided us with excellent mechanisms to recruit female and minority students from institutions where STEM research opportunities are limited, which should also enhance research capabilities within these other institutions. 

 

            The outcomes of this program were encouraging.  The statistics from the first three years are presented, since the 4th year was a reduced program partially funded by Clemson University.

 

Participant Demographics for 2017, 2018, and 2019

Total participants funded by this program (1st Three Years):  30

 

Clemson undergraduates:  (23%)         Non-Clemson undergraduates:   (77%)

Male:   18         (60%)                           Female: 12        (40%)

White, non-Hispanic:  19  (63.33%)       Asian, non-Hispanic:  3 (10%)

African American:   4  (13.33%)            Hispanic:  2 (6.67%)

Hawaiian:    1  (3.33%)                          Other:   1 (3.33%)

Total from underrepresented groups: 15 (50%)

 

            To date, over 85% of the participants have received graduate degrees, are in graduate/professional school, or are applying to graduate schools.  Most of the other students have indicated that they eventually plan to pursue graduate studies and research careers.

 

            So, it is clear that the SURE program has succeeded in preparing a significant number of students, many from underrepresented groups, for advanced education in engineering and science disciplines as well as prepared them for their future careers.  Increasing the number of diverse US citizens entering STEM fields is not only beneficial to the individual students, but to the broader society as well.

Modified by: William R Harrell
